title: 115_s1777
content:
The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes an excise tax on corporations with low-wage employees under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees based on the aggregate wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" is defined as an employer required to make tax deposits under specific chapters for more than 180 days in the previous year, excluding governmental entities, churches, and qualified church organizations. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees based on aggregate wages paid during the preceding calendar year. The term "applicable employer" excludes governmental entities, churches, and qualified church organizations. A low-wage employee is defined as an employee earning less than 218 percent of the Federal poverty line in wages from an applicable employer during the calendar year. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees earning less than 218 percent of the Federal poverty line. The amount is reduced for employees not employed for the entire year, based on the number of weeks worked. The applicable percentage is determined for tax purposes. The applicable employee ratio determines the percentage for tax purposes:
- 25% or less = 25%
- Greater than 25% but not greater than 50% = 50%
- Greater than 50% but not greater than 75% = 75%
- Greater than 75% = 100% The low-wage employee ratio is calculated as the percentage of low-wage employees to total employees. An applicable employer can reduce the applicable percentage by 25 points if they offer health and retirement benefits to full-time low-wage employees and their families. The subparagraph outlines requirements for applicable employers offering minimum essential coverage under an eligible employer-sponsored health plan to full-time low-wage employees and their families. The plan must cover at least 60% of allowed costs, with employee contributions not exceeding a set percentage of annual wages. The requirements for applicable employers offering minimum essential coverage under an eligible employer-sponsored health plan to full-time low-wage employees include ensuring that the plan covers at least 60% of allowed costs and that employee contributions do not exceed a set percentage of annual wages. Employees must also meet retirement plan requirements to be eligible for participation in applicable eligible retirement plans maintained by the employer. The term "applicable eligible retirement plan" refers to a retirement plan maintained by the employer for a plan year, which must meet specific contribution requirements. For defined contribution plans, the employer must make nonelective contributions of at least 5% of the employee's compensation. For defined benefit plans, the accrued benefit derived from employer contributions must meet certain criteria. The retirement benefit must meet specific criteria, including a minimum contribution of 5% of the employee's compensation for defined contribution plans. For defined benefit plans, the benefit calculation involves the employee's years of service and final average pay. The plan must also meet interest credit requirements and ensure a pay credit of at least 5% for the employee. The term 'eligible retirement plan' is defined as per section 402(c)(8)(B), with the inclusion of simplified employee pension accounts or annuities. Final average pay is calculated based on the consecutive years with the highest compensation from the employer, not exceeding 5 years. Final average pay is determined based on the consecutive years with the highest compensation from the employer, not exceeding 5 years. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for employers to meet requirements through a combination of defined contribution or defined benefit plans. Plans must meet requirements without considering social security contributions. Certain employees may be excluded from meeting the requirements. Certain employees may be excluded from meeting the requirements of the plan, including those under 21 years old, with less than 1 year of service, covered by a collective bargaining agreement, or nonresident aliens working outside the US. Certain employees may be excluded from meeting the plan requirements, including those covered by a collective bargaining agreement or nonresident aliens working outside the US. Definitions and special rules for wages and tax allocation are also provided. The amendments made by Chapter 37--Corporate Responsibility Tax apply to calendar years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
